questions.text: A patient presented with paronychia and lesion on the arm as shown in the image. Which of these is the most suitable antibiotic?
questions.solution:
• Paronychia is an infection of the nail fold, commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, a bacteria that is known to infect the skin and mucous membranes.
  • The typical presentation includes redness, swelling, and pus around the nail.
  • If untreated, paronychia can progress and cause complications like lymphangitis, which is the spread of infection to the lymphatic vessels, presenting as a painful, red linear erythema along the extremity.
  • Amoxiclav (a combination of amoxicillin and clavulanic acid) is a suitable broad-spectrum antibiotic that is effective against Staphylococcus aureus and can be used to treat infections like paronychia. The clavulanic acidhelps overcome resistance mechanisms (such as beta-lactamase production) in certain bacteria.

Explanation of the Incorrect Options:

  • (B) Amikacin:
    • Amikacin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, typically used for serious infections caused by gram-negative bacteria. It is not the first-line treatment for paronychia, which is primarily caused by Staphylococcus aureus, a gram-positive
  • (C) Norfloxacin:
    • Norfloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria and some gram-positive bacteria, but it is not the ideal choice for treating paronychia, which is best treated with antibiotics that target Staphylococcus aureus.
  • (D) Metronidazole:
    • Metronidazole is effective against anaerobic bacteria and protozoa but does not cover the Staphylococcus aureus infection typically seen in paronychia.

Key Takeaway: Amoxiclav is the most appropriate choice for treating paronychia, especially when caused by Staphylococcus aureus, as it covers gram-positive bacteria and prevents complications like lymphangitis.

questions.text: A 8 year old boy presents with a mild painful swelling over scalp since 3 months. He gives the history of having a pet dog at home. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp, caused by dermatophyte fungi like Trichophyton and Microsporum
  • Kerion is a severe inflammatory form of tinea capitis, where the immune system has a hypersensitivity reaction against the dermatophytes.
  • The presentation typically includes:
    • Red, boggy swelling on the scalp, which is non-tender to mildly tender.
    • The scalp may be studded with pustules.
    • There is easy pluckability of hair due to the weakened hair follicles.
    • Regional lymphadenopathy (swelling of lymph nodes) is often present.
  • In this case, the history of a pet dog is important, as zoophilic dermatophytes (those transmitted from animals, particularly dogs) are a common cause of kerion.
  • Diagnosis can be confirmed by KOH scraping, which identifies the presence of fungal elements.
  • Treatment of choice is Griseofulvin, an oral antifungal that is effective against dermatophyte infections.

Explanation of the Incorrect Options:

  • (A) Furuncle:
    • A furuncle is a boil or deep skin abscess caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is typically painful and fluctuant, but it is not associated with scalp fungal infections or lymphadenopathy like kerion.
  • (C) Dissecting cellulitis:
    • Dissecting cellulitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition of the scalp, often affecting young adults, characterized by abscess formation and scarring. It is not caused by a fungal infection and does not typically present with the features of kerion like pustules or hair pluckability.
  • (D) Abscess:
    • An abscess is a localized collection of pus due to infection, commonly caused by bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus. While an abscess may present with swelling, it is not associated with fungal infections or the typical features of kerion.

Key Takeaway: Kerion is the most likely diagnosis in this case, given the scalp swelling, mild tenderness, and history of pet dog exposure suggesting a zoophilic dermatophyte infection. The management involves oral antifungal therapy with Griseofulvin.

questions.text: A truck driver presented with complains of painless genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. The motility of the causative organism can be best checked by which microscope?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with painless genital ulcer and inguinal swelling, which is characteristic of primary syphilis.
  • Syphilis is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum, a spirochete.
  • In primary syphilis, the chancre (ulcer) is usually painless and often appears 10 to 90 days after exposure. The ulcer is often indurated and has serum oozing, which contains a large number of Treponema pallidum spirochetes.
  • Dark field microscopy is the best method to observe these spirochetes in the lesion's fluid. It provides a direct examination and allows for the identification of Treponema pallidum due to its motility, which is visible under the microscope. This technique provides immediate results, which are especially useful in diagnosing syphilis.

Explanation of the Incorrect Options:

  • (A) Electron microscope:
    • While an electron microscope can provide highly detailed images of bacteria and viruses, it is not typically used for diagnosing syphilis. It is expensive, not commonly available in clinical settings, and is not necessary for visualizing Treponema pallidum, which can be observed using a dark field microscope.
  • (C) Fluorescent microscope:
    • Fluorescent microscopy is used for detecting organisms labeled with fluorescent markers or those that naturally fluoresce, but it is not the primary tool for diagnosing syphilis. While fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption tests may be used for syphilis diagnosis, dark field microscopy is preferred for directly visualizing the spirochete in lesions.
  • (D) Light microscope:
    • A light microscope can be used to observe a wide range of organisms, but Treponema pallidum is difficult to see using standard light microscopy due to its small size and lack of natural staining. Dark field microscopy provides better contrast and visibility of spirochetes in the lesion.

Key Takeaway: For the diagnosis of syphilis and the detection of Treponema pallidum, dark field microscopy is the best diagnostic tool as it allows direct observation of the motile spirochetes in the ulcer's exudate, offering an immediate and reliable diagnosis.

questions.text: A migrant labor presented with complains of urethral discharge one week after unprotected sexual intercourse, accompanied with painful micturition. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with urethral discharge and painful micturition one week after unprotected sexual intercourse, which suggests a gonococcal infection.
  • The causative organism is Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is responsible for gonorrhea.
  • Incubation period for gonorrhea is typically 3 to 10 days after exposure.
  • Most common site of infection in men is the urethra (80%), followed by the rectum (40%) and pharynx (10%-20%).
  • Symptoms of gonococcal infection usually include copious purulent urethral discharge, dysuria (painful urination), and perimeatal erythema (redness around the urethral opening).
  • The first-line treatment for uncomplicated urogenital, anorectal, and pharyngeal gonococcal infections is:
    • Ceftriaxone 500 mg intramuscular (IM) injection as a single dose.

Incorrect Options:

  • (A) Escherichia coli:
    • While coli is a common cause of urinary tract infections (UTIs), it is not typically associated with urethral discharge and painful micturition following sexual exposure. It is more commonly seen in cystitisor pyelonephritis.
  • (C) Ureaplasma urealyticum:
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum can cause urethritis, but it is less likely to cause copious purulent dischargecompared to Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is typically associated with non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) and can cause asymptomatic or mild symptoms.
  • (D) Trichomonas vaginalis:
    • Trichomonas vaginalis causes trichomoniasis, which is associated with vaginal discharge in women and urethral discharge in men, but it tends to present with a frothy, yellow-green discharge and is less commonly associated with the purulent discharge seen in gonorrhea.

Key Takeaway: The most likely cause of urethral discharge and painful micturition in this case is Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which causes gonorrhea. The incubation period is typically 3 to 10 days, and the treatment involves a single dose of ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A 30 year old patient came with flaccid bullae which rupture easily on touch. The biopsy from the lesion is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) is an autoimmune, intraepithelial blistering disease affecting both the skin and mucous membranes.
  • Mediated by circulating autoantibodies directed against desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3, which are crucial for cell adhesion in the epidermis.
  • The principal antigen in pemphigus vulgaris is desmoglein 3.
  • The binding of antibodies to desmoglein 3 disrupts the cell-to-cell adhesion, triggering acantholysis (loss of cohesion between epidermal cells) and blister formation.
  • Clinical features include flaccid bullae that rupture easily on touch, often leading to painful erosions. Mucosal involvement, including oral ulcers, is common.
  • Suprabasal blister formation and the characteristic "tombstone appearance" of basal cells are still attached to the dermis while the upper layers are separated.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

(B) Pemphigus foliaceus:

  • Pemphigus foliaceus (PF) is another form of pemphigus where acantholysis occurs in the upper epidermis(above the granular layer), leading to subcorneal blistering. It presents with more superficial blistering and typically does not involve mucosal lesions, unlike pemphigus vulgaris.

(C) Pemphigus vegetans:

  • This rare variant of pemphigus presents with vegetative or warty lesions, usually in intertriginous areas, and does not present with flaccid bullae or mucosal involvement like pemphigus vulgaris.

(D) Erythema multiforme:

  • Erythema multiforme presents with target lesions and is generally non-vesicular, not forming the flaccid bullaeseen in pemphigus vulgaris. It also lacks the mucosal involvement associated with pemphigus vulgaris.

Key Takeaway:

The most likely diagnosis is pemphigus vulgaris, characterized by flaccid bullae that rupture easily, painful erosions, and mucosal involvement (oral ulcers). Histologically, it shows a suprabasal blister with a characteristic "tombstone appearance" on biopsy.

questions.text: A patient on MBMDT presented with inflammation over pre-existing lesions without any systemic involvement. What will be the approach to treatment?
questions.solution:
• Leprosy reactions are acute inflammatory episodes that can occur before, during, or after treatment with multi-drug therapy (MBMDT).
  • Type 1 reaction (also known as reversal reaction) is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction that mostly occurs in borderline leprosy It is characterized by inflammation of pre-existing lesions without the formation of new lesions.
  • This reaction often leads to edema, nerve thickening, and pain. In severe cases, it can worsen peripheral neuropathy, affecting sensory, motor, or autonomic
  • The main goal in managing Type 1 reaction is to suppress the cellular immune response to prevent nerve damage.
  • Steroids (especially corticosteroids) are the most effective treatment for reversing the inflammation caused by Type 1 reactions.
  • MBMDT should not be discontinued, as it remains the core treatment for leprosy, and stopping it could lead to the progression of the disease.
  • Corticosteroids are used to manage the inflammatory reaction, and the treatment approach should be continuation of MBMDT with the addition of steroids.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

(A) Stop MBMDT and start steroids:

  • Stopping MBMDT is not recommended, as it is the primary treatment for leprosy. Discontinuing the anti-leprotic drugs could lead to the disease's progression.
  • Steroids are used to manage the reaction, but stopping MBMDT would not be the appropriate approach.

(B) Stop MBMDT and start thalidomide:

  • Thalidomide is used for managing Type 2 reactions (erythema nodosum leprosum), not Type 1 reactions. Stopping MBMDT is also not recommended.

(D) Continue MBMDT and start thalidomide:

  • Thalidomide is indicated for Type 2 reactions (not Type 1 reactions) in leprosy, and its use in Type 1 reactions is not standard. The treatment of Type 1 reactions requires corticosteroids to suppress inflammation.

Key Takeaway:

The best approach to treating Type 1 leprosy reactions is to continue MBMDT and start corticosteroids to manage the inflammatory process and prevent nerve damage. Discontinuing MBMDT or using thalidomide would not be appropriate for this condition.

questions.text: What are the associated symptoms of the disease which presents with
questions.solution:
Pellagra is a nutritional disorder caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency, which leads to systemic disease with clinical manifestations affecting the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and nervous system.

The pellagra syndrome is historically characterized by the 4 D's:

  • Dermatitis
  • Diarrhea
  • Dementia
  • Death

The characteristic skin rash has a typical photosensitive distribution, with well-defined borders, mostly observed on the face, neck (forming the so-called Casal's necklace), the dorsum of the hands, and the extensor surfaces of the forearms.

Gastrointestinal involvement includes intractable diarrhea, stomatitis, and glossitis.

Neurocognitive impairment includes apathy, memory loss (dementia).

Niacin deficiency should especially be suspected in:

  • Corn/maize eaters
  • Chronic alcoholism
  • Malnutrition
  • Malabsorption
  • Hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis
  • Drugs like isoniazid, ethionamide, 6-mercaptopurine, estrogens
  • Carcinoid syndrome

Reference: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 63, page 63.15

Incorrect Options:

  • B: Alopecia - While alopecia can be seen in certain conditions like iron deficiency anemia, it is not characteristic of pellagra.
  • C: Glossitis - Glossitis is seen in pellagra but it is a part of the gastrointestinal involvement, not the primary defining symptom.
  • D: None of the above - This is incorrect, as diarrhea is a hallmark symptom of pellagra.

Key Takeaway:

Pellagra is primarily caused by niacin deficiency and manifests with the 4 D's: dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and if untreated, death. The characteristic skin rash is photosensitive, often seen on the face, neck, and hands, while gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea are commonly associated with the condition.

questions.text: A girl presented with lesions on elbows, knees and problems with seeing things at night. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Phrynoderma, also known as "follicular hyperkeratosis," presents with dry, follicular hyperkeratotic papules on a background of xerosis (dry skin), most commonly seen on the elbows and knees.
  • The history of night blindness further suggests vitamin A deficiency, which is a key factor in the development of phrynoderma.
  • Deficiencies of vitamin A, E, B complex vitamins, and essential fatty acids have been implicated in the etiology of phrynoderma. Among these, vitamin A deficiency is most characteristic.

Incorrect Answers:

  • Keratosis pilaris: This condition also presents with follicular papules but lacks the associated symptoms of night blindness, which points more toward phrynoderma.
  • Darier disease: Characterized by thickened, greasy, and crusted lesions, often with a flexural distribution. It is not associated with night blindness or a history of vitamin A deficiency.
  • Lichen planus: Presents with purple, flat-topped papules typically on the wrists, ankles, and mucous membranes. It doesn't align with the description of night blindness or dry, follicular papules.

Key Takeaway:

  • Phrynoderma is most commonly caused by vitamin A deficiency, presenting with follicular papules on dry, rough skin, particularly on the elbows and knees. It is important to consider vitamin A deficiency, especially if there is also night blindness.
